image.altText: Man in suit stands at press conference

props.synopsis: Tasmanian Premier Jeremy Rockliff says he does not need to enter into formal agreements with crossbenchers in order to form government.

title.children: Rockliff pushes on with trying to form government, says 'we don't need' deals

image.altText: A search and rescue aircraft.

props.synopsis: A pilot flying his wife and their dog across Bass Strait in a small plane did not advise authorities of the flight as required — with no distress call made before the aircraft went missing on Saturday, authorities say.

title.children: 'No distress call' from plane missing over Bass Strait, police say

image.altText: Snow covered volcanic mountain peak.

props.synopsis: Glaciers on the remote Australian territory of Heard Island have lost almost a quarter of their size over the past seven decades amid rising temperatures in the sub-Antarctic region, new research shows.

title.children: Melting glaciers on remote Australian island spark concern

image.altText: Minecraft graphic of an adult and child seated beside each other

props.synopsis: Rather than battling over device time with children, one clinical psychologist is recommending "meeting children where they are" as a first step to fostering family conversations, and even letting kids self-regulate their use.

title.children: Parent of autistic child ditches screen time rules and finds success

image.altText: George Razay with a saxophone.

props.synopsis: Dementia specialist, tap dancer, saxophonist, author, city councillor, veteran doctor, professor — George Razay has quite the resume. Now, he has added Tasmanian Member of Parliament to the list. Who is he, and what does he stand for?

title.children: Who is George Razay, sax playing doctor, opponent of Hobart stadium and new Bass MP?

image.altText: Composite image Jeremy Rockliff and Dean Winter.

props.synopsis: While the Liberals and Labor play their power games, Tasmania's parliament is paused; no legislation is being passed and the state is effectively left on standby — with the make-up the same as before the election.

title.children: Vote counting done, the deal-making begins for Tasmania's next government

image.altText: A settler teenager looks at a mobile phone while herding a flock of sheep.

props.synopsis: In the Jordan Valley in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, teenage shepherds escorted by armed security guards are trying to push Palestinian villagers from their farms.

title.children: 'Now, there's nothing stopping them': Settlers trying new forms of intimidation

image.altText: A generic shot of clinking champagne glasses in a boardroom or office.

props.synopsis: Recent surges in property values have boosted the number of Australian millionaires to a global high, the proportion of wealth held in cash and deposits is the lowest in Australia at just above 10 per cent.

title.children: 1 in 10 Australians are now millionaires: UBS report

image.altText: A shoulders-up portrait of politician Tanya Plibersek

props.synopsis: The federal frontbencher says it's a matter for Victoria whether working from home is legislated to enshrine the right for the state's employees.

title.children: 'Not marking their homework': Plibersek at ease with Vic work from home plan

image.altText: A man in a uit in a TV studio.

props.synopsis: Benjamin McCormack is facing 65 counts of using a carriage service to transmit child abuse material.

title.children: Former A Current Affair reporter facing 65 child abuse material charges

image.altText: An Intercity bus seen at the Kaiwaka bus stop

props.synopsis: A New Zealand woman is arrested after travelling on a bus with a two-year-old girl trapped in her luggage.

title.children: NZ bus driver finds child in suitcase

image.altText: A hairy brown miniature highland cow with horns.

props.synopsis: The good news is miniature Highland cows exist. The bad news is they are a lucrative trade for scammers.

title.children: Victims lose thousands of dollars in 'sophisticated' mini cow scam

image.altText: A Commonwealth Bank sign sits outside a branch of the bank, March, 2008.

props.synopsis: Analysts are tipping soft profit results, with inflation, interest rates and US tariffs all expected to weigh on company earnings as reporting season gets under way.

title.children: Warnings stock prices got 'ahead of themselves' ahead of profit reports

image.altText: Men stand in a line

props.synopsis: An alleged gangland assassin bragged "that was me, this is what we do with the cars" while showing a friend footage of gangster Bilal Hamze being killed, a court has heard.

title.children: 'Ibby's gotta go': Court hears how gangland war exploded

image.altText: Sheila Vijeyarasa with her son

props.synopsis: Perfectionism is not necessarily about achievement or structure, and can be debilitating and all-consuming.

title.children: The dark side of being a perfectionist

image.altText: An airplane on the runway

props.synopsis: Nexus says the route linking Broome and Kununurra in the Kimberley with the Northern Territory's capital has become "financially unsustainable".

title.children: Calls for flight route to be regulated after Nexus pulls out

image.altText: trainer

props.synopsis: Penrith has been handed a hefty fine and will be without a trainer for five games following a controversial incident in the NRL win over Gold Coast.

title.children: Panthers fined, trainer banned for running in front of crucial conversion attempt

image.altText: close up of blonde woman smiling in front of a white advertising wall

props.synopsis: Loni Anderson, best known for playing a struggling radio station's empowered receptionist on the hit TV comedy WKRP in Cincinnati, has died days before her 80th birthday.

title.children: WKRP in Cincinnati actor Loni Anderson dies aged 79

image.altText: Chickpeas

props.synopsis: Australian growers are planting large crops of chickpeas encouraged by a stabilised trade relationship with India.

title.children: Australian farmers regain access to world's biggest chickpea market

image.altText: Gary Edward Fitzgerald leaves court in Perth, wearing sunglasses and a dark suit.

props.synopsis: A former Perth police officer is on trial over allegations he had a sexual relationship with a teenager who believed "she couldn't say no" to him.

title.children: Ex-cop on trial over 'sex on call' relationship with teen girl

image.altText: An elderly lady smiling with two children

props.synopsis: Queensland grandmother Sheila Thurlow died in a Brisbane hospital in 2022 after she was injected with a lethal dose of morphine.

title.children: Doctor unaware syringe held 1,000 times morphine dose intended before death

image.altText: A man in a hospital bed with an oxygen mask on

props.synopsis: A Queensland family is trying to find cash to pay up-front for surgeries as 23-year-old Keanu Neilson battles a bleed on the brain and bad breaks to his arm and pelvis.

title.children: Young dad's family scrambles to raise $100k for Bali scooter crash surgery

image.altText: power pole down across white house surrounded by green fields.

props.synopsis: Emergency flood warnings remain in place in parts of NSW, as the search for a 26-year-old woman missing in the Hunter region resumes this morning.

title.children: Four emergency warnings, 20,000 without power after wild weather in NSW

image.altText: An unknown barrister wearing a legal wig and gown walking to enter a court through glass sliding doors.

props.synopsis: They are meant to deliver justice for ordinary Australians, but class actions are being used by law firms to profit at the expense of some of the most vulnerable members of society.

title.children: Barrister charged $5k-an-hour for class action that got workers as little as $10k

image.altText: Paul wears a blue business shirt and smiles, holding a silver spoon.

props.synopsis: A silver teaspoon stolen from an Edwardian era hotel in the south of England during World War II has been sent home from regional New South Wales.

title.children: Silver spoon returned to English hotel 83 years after being 'borrowed'

image.altText: The dashboard and steering wheel of a Tesla

props.synopsis: EV batteries have the potential to power a household for days and could even play a part in our future electricity grid. But not everyone supports the technology.

title.children: Tesla doesn't support using your EV to power homes or the grid

image.altText: A worker operating the furnace at the Whyalla steelworks.

props.synopsis: Some of the world's biggest steel companies have formed a consortium that could acquire the Whyalla steelworks from administration. The news comes as residents in nearby Port Pirie anxiously await an announcement about the future of their city's lead smelter.

title.children: Global steelmakers line up for potential Whyalla steelworks takeover

image.altText: CCTV footage of a store alight

props.synopsis: We can now conclude that the strategy of taxing and banning nicotine addiction out of existence is a complete failure. The result is organised crime making about $10 billion a year in revenue.

title.children: Australia's illegal tobacco problem has jumped from tragedy to farce

image.altText: Manele wears blue coat, pale shirt, striped blue tie, glasses, Albanese wears black, serious, Australia, Solomon Island flags.

props.synopsis: Solomon Islands could try to defuse a potentially explosive stoush over Taiwan's participation in a key regional meeting next month by restricting the gathering to Pacific Islands Forum members — effectively excluding China, the US and a host of other countries.

title.children: China, US could be left out of Pacific meeting as fix to brewing Taiwan row

image.altText: Lynne McGranger holds up two Gold Logie statues.

props.synopsis: Home and Away's Lynne McGranger wins the Gold Logie at the 65th awards ceremony. Meanwhile, the ABC also wins big, with Fisk taking out numerous awards.

title.children: From Lynne McGranger's wins to Sam Pang's monologue: Your key Logies moments

image.altText: A while miner's helmet signed with the names of four Chilean men, alongside rows of burning candles in the dark

props.synopsis: Chilean President Gabriel Boric has declared three days of national mourning after the deaths of five mine workers, whose bodies were recovered following a collapse at the El Teniente mine.

title.children: Chile declares three days of mourning after workers' bodies recovered in mine collapse

image.altText: a volcano eurpts sending white ash cloud high into the sky

props.synopsis: Staff at the Kronotsky Nature Reserve, where the volcano is located, say the eruption sent ash 6 kilometres into the sky.

title.children: Russian volcano erupts for first time in centuries

image.altText: John Brewster, Rick Brewster and Jane Lomax-Smith

props.synopsis: A week after placing at number 12 in the Hottest 100 of Australian Songs, rock legends The Angels have been honoured with a mural and laneway in Adelaide's CBD.

title.children: Adelaide laneway named in honour of rock band The Angels

image.altText: Alex de Minaur holds his hands up towards his head

props.synopsis: Alex de Minaur plays his best tennis on hard court and shows why again with some trademark court coverage in his win over America's Frances Tiafoe at the Canadian Open.

title.children: De Minaur uses ridiculous defence to advance at Canadian Open

image.altText: Mimi Rhodes holds her ball up after a hole-in-one

props.synopsis: Australian Steph Kyriacou is involved in another hole-in-one, this time for a rival player, as Japan's Miyu Yamashita takes out the Women's British Open.

title.children: Tee shot bounces off Aussie's ball for hole-in-one at British Open
